THE NSSC NEWSLETTER"
Published quarterly by the Na¬
tional Society for the Study of
Communication and distributed to
NSSC members.
EDITOR-Dr. Donald E. Bird, Exec¬
utive Secretary, NSSC, Stephens
College, Columbia, Missouri.
Committees Need Help
I would like to hear from the
membership on specific projects
each of you think should occupy the
attention of one or more study and
research committees. If you have
access to methods, personnel, data,
areas that might be valuable in car¬
rying on a particular project, let me
know.
Some of the specific suggestions
for study and research which have
been made are: (1) A study of jar¬
gon; (2) A study of the effect of
stress upon words; (3) A study of
the direction of meaning; (4) A
study of the irresponsible use of
language; and (5) A study of the
mis-use of language in important
Congressional hearings. What do
you think of these suggestions?
—Joe Baccus
We Are too Academic!
It has been brought to my atten¬
tion that the tenor of our publica¬
tions is primarily academic, and
addressed mostly to members of the
academic profession. While this is
true, it is not what was intended by
those who organized the Society.
One of the principal reasons why
I joined NSSC in its first year was
the hope that the new organization
could go beyond the capabilities oF
any one group, and do something
useful by combining the capabilities
of communication-minded people
from all the academic disciplines
with those of similar people in busi¬
ness and industry and government.
However, NSSC was sparked at
first, and for the most part is still
sparked, by teachers or former
teachers. This may explain the tenor
of our publications, but it also con¬
fesses that as yet we have not suc¬
ceeded in establishing an enterprise
which utilizes the forces of a full
partnership of people from many
professions.
Effective communication is a con¬
cern of all leaders, and the study of
communication is an exercise re¬
quisite to success in any leadership
Page 2
function, such as being a good par¬
ent, or a good teacher, or a good ad¬
ministrator or executive. NSSC can
do its best work by coordinating the
efforts of capable persons in all lines
of endeavor.
Our editors, however, can publish
only what is submitted. Only as our
non-teacher members come through
with something to print can the
tenor of our publications be modi¬
fied. Our editors do in fact bend
over backward to publish every¬
thing that is submitted by repre¬
sentatives of business or govern¬
ment. —Burt Byers
Chapters Have Value
(Editor’s Note: When the Portland
Chapter was re-organized in Febru¬
ary, nine members addressed a letter
to interested persons setting forth
clearly and aptly the purpose and
value of the local chapter and its rela¬
tionship to NSSC. I am quoting from
that letter, hoping that the ideas may
be helpful to members of other local
chapters and to persons considering
the organization of new chapters.)
“The purpose of a local chapter
should be to bring together people
from various walks of life who are
interested in and working on the
problems of communication, people
who, in addition, recognize the spe¬
cial value for such ends of a national
group which sponsors study and
activity in all parts of the nation
and in various groups whose policies
and principles influence the course
our culture takes in its growth.”
“The chief value of a local chapter,
aside from furnishing a channel of
communication with the national or¬
ganization, would be that through
it the members would be kept sys¬
tematically informed of the insights
and developments among our local
members as to the nature and prob¬
lems of human intercommunication
processes. But that is not all. At
least two or three other values ought
to be listed: the opportunity to ex¬
plore the importance of the insights
and developments in our field of
interest for each other, our families,
our community, and our enterprises;
the opportunity, also, for members
to explain their own methods of us¬
ing communication in personal and/
or group relations—and to receive
constructive criticism of those meth¬
ods; and the satisfaction, ultimately,
of making a contribution at the
grass-roots toward the improvement
of human life by the influence of
our chapter upon the growth of in¬
dividuals.”
Committee Reports
Colleges and Universities
Immediate objectives of the com¬
mittee are: (1) To determine the
curricular structure of a course in
communications; (2) To submit the
course to NSSS members for exami¬
nation and refinement; (3) To pub¬
lish the results in the form of a
syllabus; (5) To submit the syllabus
to educators for possible use; (6) To
seek to bring institutions, course
and teachers together; and (7) To
stress experimentation in summer
session activities.
—Granville Basye
Elementary Education
The specific tasks which we shall
tackle this year are: (1) Develop¬
ment of basic principles upon which
to build communication programs
for elementary schools; (2) Devel¬
opment of specific objectives for
such programs; and (3) Evaluation
of existing programs.
Committee members are Mrs.
Dorothy Miller and Frank Roberts.
—Delpha Hurlburt
Family and Community
Two projects for the current year
are: (1) A study of recent attacks
on public education in relation to
parent-child, family-c o m m u n i t y
communication; and (2) An explor¬
ation of language and non-language
symbols of the marriage relation¬
ship as these symbols relate to the
problem of an excessive divorce rate.
Theodore Johannis is a new mem¬
ber of the committee.
—Elwood Murray
Mass Media
Committee objectives are as fol¬
lows: (1) To collect information and
data about mass communication and
make it available to interested per¬
sons through the publications, con¬
ventions and other facilities of the
society; (2) To provide concrete
guidance and assistance to persons
working on problems in mass com¬
munication.
(3) To develop programs in mass
communication at the meetings and
conventions of not only the society
but of other interested organizations
as well; (4) To identify existing
problems in mass communication
and find the appropriate agencies
or individuals to seek solutions; and
